column1: About ten o'clock on the following morning
column3: I was dragging myself along Portland Place
column4: when a child that was passing
column6: tossed a luscious big pear — minus one bite — into the gutter. I stopped
column8: and fastened my desiring eye on that muddy treasure. My mouth watered for it
column10: my whole being begged for it. But every time I made a move to get it some passing eye detected my purpose
column11: and of course I straightened up then
column13: and pretended that I hadn't been thinking about the pear at all. This same thing kept happening and happening
column14: and I couldn't get the pear. I was just getting desperate enough to brave all the shame
column16: when a window behind me was raised
column17: and a gentleman spoke out of it
